title: X and Y Intercepts in Quadratic Functions

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=x^2+5x+6` ?
questionList.solution: The two x-intercepts are -2 and -3 because `f(x)=x^2+5x+6=(x+2)(x+3)`, so the two intercepts are `x+2=0, x=-2` and `x+3=0, x=-3`.

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=x^2+4x+4` ?
questionList.solution: The two x-intercept is -2 because `f(x)=x^2+4x+4=(x+2)^2`, so the intercept are `x+2=0, x=-2`.

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=9x^2+6x+1` ?
questionList.solution: The x-intercept is `-1/3` because `f(x)=9x^2+6x+1=(3x+1)^2`, so the two intercepts are `3x+1=0, x=-1/3`.

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=x^2-9x+20` ?
questionList.solution: The two x-intercepts are 4 and 5 because `f(x)=x^2-9x+20=(x-4)(x-5)`, so the two intercepts are `x-4=0, x=4` and `x-5=0, x=5`.

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=x^2-21x-72` ?
questionList.solution: The two x-intercepts are 24 and -3 because `f(x)=x^2-21x-72=(x-24)(x+3)`, so the two intercepts are `x-24=0, x=24` and `x+3=0, x=-3`.

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=25x^2-16` ?
questionList.solution: The two x-intercepts are 4/5 and -4/5 because `f(x)=25x^2-16=(5x-4)(5x+4)`, so the two intercepts are `5x-4=0, x=4/5` and `5x+4=0, x=-4/5`.

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=x^2-16x+63` ?
questionList.solution: The two x-intercepts are 7 and 9 because `f(x)=x^2-16x+63=(x-7)(x-9)`, so the two intercepts are `x-7=0, x=7` and `x-9=0, x=9`.

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=7x^2+9x` ?
questionList.solution: The two x-intercepts are 0 and -7/9 because `f(x)=7x^2+9x=x(7x+9)`, so the two intercepts are `x=0` and `7x+9=0, x=-9/7`.

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=5x^2-x-18x` ?
questionList.solution: The two x-intercepts are -9/5 and 2 because `f(x)=5x^2-x-18=(5x+9)(x-2)`, so the two intercepts are `5x+9=0, x=-9/5` and `x-2=0, x=2`.

questionList.qu: What is/are the x-intercepts(s) of the function `f(x)=7x^2-45x-28` ?
questionList.solution: The two x-intercepts are -4/7 and 7 because `f(x)=7x^2-45x-28=(7x+4)(x-7)`, so the two intercepts are `7x+4=0, x=-4/7` and `x-7=0, x=7`.

questionList.qu: If a quadratic function has the x-intercepts `-9999` and `-1/4`, what is its equation?
questionList.solution: The equation is `f(x)=(x+9999)(x+1/4)`.

questionList.qu: If a quadratic function has the x-intercepts `10/3` and `10/13`, what is its equation?
questionList.solution: The equation is `f(x)=(3x-10)(13x-10)`.

questionList.qu: The x-intercept...
questionList.a1: Is where function crosses the y-axis
questionList.a2: Is/are the x coordinate(s) when y=0
questionList.a3: Is the greatest value of the function
questionList.a4: Only exists when the function is a quadratic function
questionList.solution: The x-intercept is/are the x coordinate(s) when y=0`.

questionList.qu: How many x-intercepts does `f(x)=x^2+4` have?
questionList.solution: `f(x)=x^2+4` has 0 x-intercepts because its graph does not touch the x-axis.

questionList.qu: How many x-intercepts does `f(x)=(x-4)^2-1` have?
questionList.solution: `f(x)=(x-4)^2-1` has 2 x-intercepts because it can be factored into `f(x)=(x-3)(x-5)`.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=3x^2-10x+9` ?
questionList.solution: When a quadratic function is in its standard form (`f(x)=ax^2+bx+c`), the y-intercept is always c, so in this case, 9.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=1000x^2-99x+1` ?
questionList.solution: When a quadratic function is in its standard form (`f(x)=ax^2+bx+c`), the y-intercept is always c, so in this case, 1.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=9x^2-x` ?
questionList.solution: When a quadratic function is in its standard form (`f(x)=ax^2+bx+c`), the y-intercept is always c, so in this case, 0.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=77x^2-66x+77-66` ?
questionList.solution: When a quadratic function is in its standard form (`f(x)=ax^2+bx+c`), the y-intercept is always c, so in this case, 77-66=11.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=4x^2-x-4x+9` ?
questionList.solution: When a quadratic function is in its standard form (`f(x)=ax^2+bx+c`), the y-intercept is always c, so in this case, 9.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=(x+10)(x-1)` ?
questionList.solution: If you convert `f(x)=(x+10)(x-1)` into its standard form, you will find that the y-intercept is -10.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=(x+13)^2` ?
questionList.solution: If you convert `f(x)=(x+13)^2` into its standard form, you will find that the y-intercept is 169.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=(x-17)^2` ?
questionList.solution: If you convert `f(x)=(x-17)^2` into its standard form, you will find that the y-intercept is 289.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=(x+6)^2-4` ?
questionList.solution: If you convert `f(x)=(x+6)^2-4` into its standard form, you will find that the y-intercept is 32.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=(x+3)^2-4` ?
questionList.solution: If you convert `f(x)=(x+3)^2-4` into its standard form, you will find that the y-intercept is 5.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=(x+9)(10x-1)` ?
questionList.solution: If you convert `f(x)=(x+13)^2-101` into its standard form, you will find that the y-intercept is 68.

questionList.qu: What is the y-intercept of the function `f(x)=(2x+3)(x+7)` ?
questionList.solution: If you convert `f(x)=(2x+3)(x+7)` into its standard form, you will find that the y-intercept is 21.

questionList.qu: If `c=3, f(x)=50x+25+10-4c`, what is the y-intercept of the `f(x)`?
questionList.solution: The y-intercept is `10-4c=10-12=-2`.

questionList.qu: How do you find the y-intercept of a function?
questionList.a1: Plug y=0 into the function and solve for x
questionList.a2: Find the recipricols of the zeros of the function
questionList.a3: Plug x=0 into the function and solve for y
questionList.a4: The y-intercept is always the constant of the function
questionList.solution: You always find the y-intercept of a function by plugging x=0 into the function and solving for y.

questionList.qu: When do quadratic functions don't have y-intercepts?
questionList.a2: When there is no constant in the equation
questionList.a3: When the coefficient of the quadratic term is negative
questionList.solution: Quadratic functions always have y-intercepts.
